BIOS224
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation due to commence September 2024, starting in year 2.

Overview

Overview
This is an elective residential field course in an Afrotropical location. The aim of this module is to introduce students to the ecology of Afrotropical ecosystems and the field techniques used to study them, through staff-led field visits, seminars and student executed field studies.

The module may include topics such as ecosystem function, patterns of habitat regeneration, patterns of biodiversity, the natural history of important plant and animal taxa, and behavioural ecology. Interactions between humans and ecosystems will also be a key focus, with conservation, sustainable development, human-wildlife conflict and ecotourism also being addressed.

The module will be assessed by continuous assessments. In the event of unforeseen circumstances that prevent either individual students attending (e.g. illness shortly before departure) or cancellation of the trip (e.g. on FCDO and/or University insurer advice), local alternate assessment exercises will be made available. These will predominantly be library-based, but might involve field visits where possible to practice field skills.
Educational Aims
Introduce students to the ecology of Afrotropical ecosystems and the field techniques used to study them, through staff-led field visits, seminars and student executed field studies;

Train students in how to design, execute, and present research projects conducted in the field;

Allow students to explore interactions between humans and Afrotropical ecosystems, with sustainable development, effects of habitat loss and human wildlife conflict and eco-tourism being addressed;

Develop in students knowledge and understanding in tropical ecology, and the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve ecological problems
Marketing Module Synopsis
This elective residential field course takes place in an Afrotropical setting and aims to familiarise students with the ecology of ecosystems outside of Europe and the field techniques utilised in their study. This will be accomplished through a combination of staff-led field visits, seminars, and student-conducted field studies.

The content of the module may encompass various aspects such as ecosystem function, patterns of habitat regeneration, biodiversity patterns, the natural history of significant plant and animal groups, and behavioural ecology. Additionally, the module will explore human-ecosystem interactions, focusing on topics like conservation, sustainable development, human-wildlife conflict, and ecotourism.

Assessment for this module will be conducted through continuous assessments. In situations where individual students are unable to attend due to unforeseen circumstances such as illness shortly before departure, or if the trip is cancelled based on advice from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and/or University insurer, alternative local assessment exercises will be provided. These exercises will mainly be library-based but may also include field visits where feasible, allowing students to practice field skills
Outline Syllabus
Concept and origins of Afrotropical diversity;

Geography and climate of the tropics;

Insect taxonomy;

Introduction to mammalian fauna, herpetofauna, and avifauna;

Predator-prey interactions;

Animal – plant interactions;

Dung beetle ecology;

Herbivory, seed predation and dispersal

Mammalian and avian behavioural ecology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1
Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover theory and context to the field skills. Also incorporate application of wider transferable skills to practical problem solving. Also includes field trip follow-up lectures at the end of each session in the field
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: Meetings in Liverpool prior to departure to discuss expectations, logistical arrangements, Health and Safety, student conduct, and fieldwork orientation
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3
Field Work: Time spent in the field. Several practical activities will be carried out, ranging from identification, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions. This includes time spent in the field carrying out group-study and research projects
Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4 - Group Project
Description: Small group (4-5 students) research projects supervised by UoL staff. With guidance from staff, students design and execute a research project, either observational or experimental, on some aspect of animal behaviour. Students will be required to work in an ethical and safe manner. This group project will include a joint production and delivery of an oral presentation of the research conducted.
Attendance Recorded: Not yet decided


The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of biosciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent animal behaviour, ecology and behavioural scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of field skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for the fieldwork and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Experimental and field techniques within the Biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of field methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are four assessment components. The project write-up requires students showcase their aptitude for field skills and experiment design and application of the theoretical knowledge. The 'field note book' is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of field based skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise and professional manner. The oral presentation will allow students to showcase their understanding and development as field biologists. Finally, the 'satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course' assesses students overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Fieldwork sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex fieldwork, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a fieldwork builds confidence in technical skills and application of theoretical knowledge and provides students with an awareness of good field practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a natural environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both field-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate hands-on and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into fieldwork teaching with the use of experimental applications, and methodologies that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency critically reviewing literature in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on field related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via four assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:
1. Project write up (weighting 40%) based on skills developed in field and is effectively a scientific report that includes experimental design, hypotheses testing, data collection, analysis and interpretation, and scientific synthesis of findings with the literature. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

2. Field note book (weighting 40%) based on notes made real-time during field based activities. Maintaining a fieldwork note book is a highly authentic assessment and a required skill for professional ecologists. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

3. Oral presentation (weighting 10%) of field based project. This is a timed presentation to staff and peers (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

4. Satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course (10%), assesses students' overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork principles.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies only to assessment 1 since the nature and timing of the remaining assessments (2, 3, and 4) are completed on the field course and there is no opportunity for late submission.
Assessment 1 is anonymous but Assessments 2, 3, and 4 cannot be anonymous since (a) assessment 2 is a notebook in which students must include their names/personal details and reflect on activities in a contemporaneous manner, (b) assessment 3 is an oral presentation, and (c) assessment 4 is based on student performance and contribution to field course activities.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available (assessments 1 and 3) and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark) unless students have approved Extenuating Circumstances. There not a resit opportunity for assessment 4 because it assesses students’ activities in the field, which cannot be replicated in a resit. We have selected no resit opportunity for assessment 2 because it is a contemporaneous record of field course activities and reflections while on the field course. It will not be possible to resit this assessment in the resit period (August) without returning to the field site, which is not possible.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Bachelor's with Honours
 ReferenceOutcome 
 BH1 Explain the origin and maintenance of Afrotropical forest ecosystems and processes influencing biodiversity and ecosystem dynamics in Afrotropical habitats;
 BH2 Identify the basic groups of Afrotropical taxa, with emphasis on insects, mammals, birds, reptiles and plants and the natural history of important plant and animal taxa;
 BH3 Appraise conceptual issues underlying current research programmes in tropical environments including issues of human impact, conservation biology, and sustainable use of Afrotropical ecosystems;
 BH4 Collate, analyze and interpret field data;
 BH5 Critically evaluate the principles of ecology, and how this knowledge has been applied to solve ecological problems.

There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on field related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via four assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:
1. Project write up (weighting 40%) based on skills developed in field and is effectively a scientific report that includes experimental design, hypotheses testing, data collection, analysis and interpretation, and scientific synthesis of findings with the literature. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

2. Field note book (weighting 40%) based on notes made real-time during field based activities. Maintaining a fieldwork note book is a highly authentic assessment and a required skill for professional ecologists. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

3. Oral presentation (weighting 10%) of field based project. This is a timed presentation to staff and peers (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

4. Satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course (10%), assesses students' overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork principles.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies only to assessment 1 since the nature and timing of the remaining assessments (2, 3, and 4) are completed on the field course and there is no opportunity for late submission.
Assessment 1 is anonymous but Assessments 2, 3, and 4 cannot be anonymous since (a) assessment 2 is a notebook in which students must include their names/personal details and reflect on activities in a contemporaneous manner, (b) assessment 3 is an oral presentation, and (c) assessment 4 is based on student performance and contribution to field course activities.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available (assessments 1 and 3) and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark) unless students have approved Extenuating Circumstances. There not a resit opportunity for assessment 4 because it assesses students’ activities in the field, which cannot be replicated in a resit. We have selected no resit opportunity for assessment 2 because it is a contemporaneous record of field course activities and reflections while on the field course. It will not be possible to resit this assessment in the resit period (August) without returning to the field site, which is not possible.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS224
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation due to commence September 2024, starting in year 2.

Overview

Overview
This is an elective residential field course in an Afrotropical location. The aim of this module is to introduce students to the ecology of Afrotropical ecosystems and the field techniques used to study them, through staff-led field visits, seminars and student executed field studies.

The module may include topics such as ecosystem function, patterns of habitat regeneration, patterns of biodiversity, the natural history of important plant and animal taxa, and behavioural ecology. Interactions between humans and ecosystems will also be a key focus, with conservation, sustainable development, human-wildlife conflict and ecotourism also being addressed.

The module will be assessed by continuous assessments. In the event of unforeseen circumstances that prevent either individual students attending (e.g. illness shortly before departure) or cancellation of the trip (e.g. on FCDO and/or University insurer advice), local alternate assessment exercises will be made available. These will predominantly be library-based, but might involve field visits where possible to practice field skills.
Educational Aims
Introduce students to the ecology of Afrotropical ecosystems and the field techniques used to study them, through staff-led field visits, seminars and student executed field studies;

Train students in how to design, execute, and present research projects conducted in the field;

Allow students to explore interactions between humans and Afrotropical ecosystems, with sustainable development, effects of habitat loss and human wildlife conflict and eco-tourism being addressed;

Develop in students knowledge and understanding in tropical ecology, and the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve ecological problems
Marketing Module Synopsis
This elective residential field course takes place in an Afrotropical setting and aims to familiarise students with the ecology of ecosystems outside of Europe and the field techniques utilised in their study. This will be accomplished through a combination of staff-led field visits, seminars, and student-conducted field studies.

The content of the module may encompass various aspects such as ecosystem function, patterns of habitat regeneration, biodiversity patterns, the natural history of significant plant and animal groups, and behavioural ecology. Additionally, the module will explore human-ecosystem interactions, focusing on topics like conservation, sustainable development, human-wildlife conflict, and ecotourism.

Assessment for this module will be conducted through continuous assessments. In situations where individual students are unable to attend due to unforeseen circumstances such as illness shortly before departure, or if the trip is cancelled based on advice from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and/or University insurer, alternative local assessment exercises will be provided. These exercises will mainly be library-based but may also include field visits where feasible, allowing students to practice field skills
Outline Syllabus
Concept and origins of Afrotropical diversity;

Geography and climate of the tropics;

Insect taxonomy;

Introduction to mammalian fauna, herpetofauna, and avifauna;

Predator-prey interactions;

Animal – plant interactions;

Dung beetle ecology;

Herbivory, seed predation and dispersal

Mammalian and avian behavioural ecology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1
Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover theory and context to the field skills. Also incorporate application of wider transferable skills to practical problem solving. Also includes field trip follow-up lectures at the end of each session in the field
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: Meetings in Liverpool prior to departure to discuss expectations, logistical arrangements, Health and Safety, student conduct, and fieldwork orientation
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3
Field Work: Time spent in the field. Several practical activities will be carried out, ranging from identification, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions. This includes time spent in the field carrying out group-study and research projects
Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4 - Group Project
Description: Small group (4-5 students) research projects supervised by UoL staff. With guidance from staff, students design and execute a research project, either observational or experimental, on some aspect of animal behaviour. Students will be required to work in an ethical and safe manner. This group project will include a joint production and delivery of an oral presentation of the research conducted.
Attendance Recorded: Not yet decided


The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of biosciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent animal behaviour, ecology and behavioural scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of field skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for the fieldwork and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Experimental and field techniques within the Biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of field methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are four assessment components. The project write-up requires students showcase their aptitude for field skills and experiment design and application of the theoretical knowledge. The 'field note book' is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of field based skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise and professional manner. The oral presentation will allow students to showcase their understanding and development as field biologists. Finally, the 'satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course' assesses students overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Fieldwork sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex fieldwork, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a fieldwork builds confidence in technical skills and application of theoretical knowledge and provides students with an awareness of good field practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a natural environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both field-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate hands-on and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into fieldwork teaching with the use of experimental applications, and methodologies that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency critically reviewing literature in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on field related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via four assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:
1. Project write up (weighting 40%) based on skills developed in field and is effectively a scientific report that includes experimental design, hypotheses testing, data collection, analysis and interpretation, and scientific synthesis of findings with the literature. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

2. Field note book (weighting 40%) based on notes made real-time during field based activities. Maintaining a fieldwork note book is a highly authentic assessment and a required skill for professional ecologists. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

3. Oral presentation (weighting 10%) of field based project. This is a timed presentation to staff and peers (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

4. Satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course (10%), assesses students' overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork principles.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies only to assessment 1 since the nature and timing of the remaining assessments (2, 3, and 4) are completed on the field course and there is no opportunity for late submission.
Assessment 1 is anonymous but Assessments 2, 3, and 4 cannot be anonymous since (a) assessment 2 is a notebook in which students must include their names/personal details and reflect on activities in a contemporaneous manner, (b) assessment 3 is an oral presentation, and (c) assessment 4 is based on student performance and contribution to field course activities.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available (assessments 1 and 3) and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark) unless students have approved Extenuating Circumstances. There not a resit opportunity for assessment 4 because it assesses students’ activities in the field, which cannot be replicated in a resit. We have selected no resit opportunity for assessment 2 because it is a contemporaneous record of field course activities and reflections while on the field course. It will not be possible to resit this assessment in the resit period (August) without returning to the field site, which is not possible.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS224
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation due to commence September 2024, starting in year 2.

Overview

Overview
This is an elective residential field course in an Afrotropical location. The aim of this module is to introduce students to the ecology of Afrotropical ecosystems and the field techniques used to study them, through staff-led field visits, seminars and student executed field studies.

The module may include topics such as ecosystem function, patterns of habitat regeneration, patterns of biodiversity, the natural history of important plant and animal taxa, and behavioural ecology. Interactions between humans and ecosystems will also be a key focus, with conservation, sustainable development, human-wildlife conflict and ecotourism also being addressed.

The module will be assessed by continuous assessments. In the event of unforeseen circumstances that prevent either individual students attending (e.g. illness shortly before departure) or cancellation of the trip (e.g. on FCDO and/or University insurer advice), local alternate assessment exercises will be made available. These will predominantly be library-based, but might involve field visits where possible to practice field skills.
Educational Aims
Introduce students to the ecology of Afrotropical ecosystems and the field techniques used to study them, through staff-led field visits, seminars and student executed field studies;

Train students in how to design, execute, and present research projects conducted in the field;

Allow students to explore interactions between humans and Afrotropical ecosystems, with sustainable development, effects of habitat loss and human wildlife conflict and eco-tourism being addressed;

Develop in students knowledge and understanding in tropical ecology, and the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve ecological problems
Marketing Module Synopsis
This elective residential field course takes place in an Afrotropical setting and aims to familiarise students with the ecology of ecosystems outside of Europe and the field techniques utilised in their study. This will be accomplished through a combination of staff-led field visits, seminars, and student-conducted field studies.

The content of the module may encompass various aspects such as ecosystem function, patterns of habitat regeneration, biodiversity patterns, the natural history of significant plant and animal groups, and behavioural ecology. Additionally, the module will explore human-ecosystem interactions, focusing on topics like conservation, sustainable development, human-wildlife conflict, and ecotourism.

Assessment for this module will be conducted through continuous assessments. In situations where individual students are unable to attend due to unforeseen circumstances such as illness shortly before departure, or if the trip is cancelled based on advice from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and/or University insurer, alternative local assessment exercises will be provided. These exercises will mainly be library-based but may also include field visits where feasible, allowing students to practice field skills
Outline Syllabus
Concept and origins of Afrotropical diversity;

Geography and climate of the tropics;

Insect taxonomy;

Introduction to mammalian fauna, herpetofauna, and avifauna;

Predator-prey interactions;

Animal – plant interactions;

Dung beetle ecology;

Herbivory, seed predation and dispersal

Mammalian and avian behavioural ecology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1
Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover theory and context to the field skills. Also incorporate application of wider transferable skills to practical problem solving. Also includes field trip follow-up lectures at the end of each session in the field
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: Meetings in Liverpool prior to departure to discuss expectations, logistical arrangements, Health and Safety, student conduct, and fieldwork orientation
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3
Field Work: Time spent in the field. Several practical activities will be carried out, ranging from identification, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions. This includes time spent in the field carrying out group-study and research projects
Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4 - Group Project
Description: Small group (4-5 students) research projects supervised by UoL staff. With guidance from staff, students design and execute a research project, either observational or experimental, on some aspect of animal behaviour. Students will be required to work in an ethical and safe manner. This group project will include a joint production and delivery of an oral presentation of the research conducted.
Attendance Recorded: Not yet decided


The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of biosciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent animal behaviour, ecology and behavioural scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of field skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for the fieldwork and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Experimental and field techniques within the Biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of field methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are four assessment components. The project write-up requires students showcase their aptitude for field skills and experiment design and application of the theoretical knowledge. The 'field note book' is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of field based skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise and professional manner. The oral presentation will allow students to showcase their understanding and development as field biologists. Finally, the 'satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course' assesses students overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Fieldwork sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex fieldwork, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a fieldwork builds confidence in technical skills and application of theoretical knowledge and provides students with an awareness of good field practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a natural environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both field-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate hands-on and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into fieldwork teaching with the use of experimental applications, and methodologies that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency critically reviewing literature in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on field related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via four assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:
1. Project write up (weighting 40%) based on skills developed in field and is effectively a scientific report that includes experimental design, hypotheses testing, data collection, analysis and interpretation, and scientific synthesis of findings with the literature. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

2. Field note book (weighting 40%) based on notes made real-time during field based activities. Maintaining a fieldwork note book is a highly authentic assessment and a required skill for professional ecologists. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

3. Oral presentation (weighting 10%) of field based project. This is a timed presentation to staff and peers (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

4. Satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course (10%), assesses students' overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork principles.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies only to assessment 1 since the nature and timing of the remaining assessments (2, 3, and 4) are completed on the field course and there is no opportunity for late submission.
Assessment 1 is anonymous but Assessments 2, 3, and 4 cannot be anonymous since (a) assessment 2 is a notebook in which students must include their names/personal details and reflect on activities in a contemporaneous manner, (b) assessment 3 is an oral presentation, and (c) assessment 4 is based on student performance and contribution to field course activities.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available (assessments 1 and 3) and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark) unless students have approved Extenuating Circumstances. There not a resit opportunity for assessment 4 because it assesses students’ activities in the field, which cannot be replicated in a resit. We have selected no resit opportunity for assessment 2 because it is a contemporaneous record of field course activities and reflections while on the field course. It will not be possible to resit this assessment in the resit period (August) without returning to the field site, which is not possible.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Bachelor's with Honours
 ReferenceOutcome 
 BH1 Explain the origin and maintenance of Afrotropical forest ecosystems and processes influencing biodiversity and ecosystem dynamics in Afrotropical habitats;
 BH2 Identify the basic groups of Afrotropical taxa, with emphasis on insects, mammals, birds, reptiles and plants and the natural history of important plant and animal taxa;
 BH3 Appraise conceptual issues underlying current research programmes in tropical environments including issues of human impact, conservation biology, and sustainable use of Afrotropical ecosystems;
 BH4 Collate, analyze and interpret field data;
 BH5 Critically evaluate the principles of ecology, and how this knowledge has been applied to solve ecological problems.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of biosciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent animal behaviour, ecology and behavioural scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of field skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for the fieldwork and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Experimental and field techniques within the Biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of field methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are four assessment components. The project write-up requires students showcase their aptitude for field skills and experiment design and application of the theoretical knowledge. The 'field note book' is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of field based skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise and professional manner. The oral presentation will allow students to showcase their understanding and development as field biologists. Finally, the 'satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course' assesses students overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Fieldwork sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex fieldwork, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a fieldwork builds confidence in technical skills and application of theoretical knowledge and provides students with an awareness of good field practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a natural environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both field-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate hands-on and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into fieldwork teaching with the use of experimental applications, and methodologies that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency critically reviewing literature in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on field related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via four assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:
1. Project write up (weighting 40%) based on skills developed in field and is effectively a scientific report that includes experimental design, hypotheses testing, data collection, analysis and interpretation, and scientific synthesis of findings with the literature. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

2. Field note book (weighting 40%) based on notes made real-time during field based activities. Maintaining a fieldwork note book is a highly authentic assessment and a required skill for professional ecologists. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

3. Oral presentation (weighting 10%) of field based project. This is a timed presentation to staff and peers (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

4. Satisfactory completion of tasks on the field course (10%), assesses students' overall professionalism and conduct in the field which also includes adhering to appropriate H&S, ethical and sustainable fieldwork principles.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies only to assessment 1 since the nature and timing of the remaining assessments (2, 3, and 4) are completed on the field course and there is no opportunity for late submission.
Assessment 1 is anonymous but Assessments 2, 3, and 4 cannot be anonymous since (a) assessment 2 is a notebook in which students must include their names/personal details and reflect on activities in a contemporaneous manner, (b) assessment 3 is an oral presentation, and (c) assessment 4 is based on student performance and contribution to field course activities.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available (assessments 1 and 3) and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark) unless students have approved Extenuating Circumstances. There not a resit opportunity for assessment 4 because it assesses students’ activities in the field, which cannot be replicated in a resit. We have selected no resit opportunity for assessment 2 because it is a contemporaneous record of field course activities and reflections while on the field course. It will not be possible to resit this assessment in the resit period (August) without returning to the field site, which is not possible.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Bachelor's with Honours
 ReferenceOutcome 
 BH1 Explain the origin and maintenance of Afrotropical forest ecosystems and processes influencing biodiversity and ecosystem dynamics in Afrotropical habitats;
 BH2 Identify the basic groups of Afrotropical taxa, with emphasis on insects, mammals, birds, reptiles and plants and the natural history of important plant and animal taxa;
 BH3 Appraise conceptual issues underlying current research programmes in tropical environments including issues of human impact, conservation biology, and sustainable use of Afrotropical ecosystems;
 BH4 Collate, analyze and interpret field data;
 BH5 Critically evaluate the principles of ecology, and how this knowledge has been applied to solve ecological problems.
